skills.name: Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles
Find missing angles on parallel lines using alternate angles
Find missing angles on parallel lines using more than one angle fact

explanations.A: Remember, angles on a line sum to 180°
explanations.B: We can find a corresponding angle to a, and then use angles on a straight line to do 180 - 103 = 77
explanations.C: What kind of angle is a? Are these equal?
explanations.D: Remember, angles on a line sum to 180. Can you use the parallel lines to find equal angles?

explanations.A: How do we mark parallel lines? Look carefully at which lines are parallel.

explanations.C: d and l are corresponding, as they are in matching corners on parallel lines

explanations.A: 12+78 would make a right angle. Would these fit together to make a right angle?
explanations.C: I think you may be thinking of co-interior angles, which sum to 180. What kind of angles are these?
explanations.D: I think you may be thinking of angles around a point, which sum to 360. What kind of angles are these?

explanations.A: 15+65 would make a right angle. Would these fit together to make a right angle?
explanations.B: I think you may be thinking of co-interior angles, which sum to 180. What kind of angles are these?
explanations.D: I think you may be thinking of angles around a point, which sum to 360. What kind of angles are these?

explanations.B: I think you may be thinking of co-interior angles, which sum to 180. What kind of angles are these?
explanations.C: What kind of angles are these? e.g. Alternate, co-interior, corresponding, vertically opposite, etc.
explanations.D: Try marking parallel lines with arrows, does this look any more familiar?

explanations.A: Angles on a straight line add up to 180° but these two angles are alternate angles. What is the rule for alternate angles?
explanations.B: I think you might have estimated the size of the angle but we can work it out. We have two alternate angles here. What do we know about alternate angles?
explanations.C: Angle q and the 125° angle marked on the diagram are alternate angles on a pair of parallel lines. We know that alternate angles are equal so angle q must also equal 125°.
explanations.D: We can use a rule about angles on parallel lines to work this out. Are the two angles shown corresponding, alternate or on a straight line?

explanations.A: Angle q and the 65° angle marked on the diagram are alternate angles on a pair of parallel lines. We know that alternate angles are equal so angle q must also equal 65°.
explanations.B: Angles on a straight line add up to 180° but these two angles are alternate angles. What is the rule for alternate angles?
